title: How to Drill Metal

steps.headline: Select the right bit for the job.
steps.description: High speed steel (HSS) bits will work for most kinds of metal, as will carbon steel bits coated with titanium nitride (TiN). For very hard metals, use a cobalt steel bit.

steps.headline: Secure a loose piece of metal you're drilling by clamping it to your workstation or setting it in a vice.
steps.description: This step is not necessary if drilling into a large, heavy steel object like a wall or stud.

steps.headline: Mark the position you need to drill with a pencil.
steps.description: Measure this area with precision, since it's harder to patch a mistake in metal than to patch one you've made in wood.

steps.headline: Set the center in place on the pencil mark.
steps.description: Hit it lightly with the hammer to mark your drill point and create a starting divot.

steps.headline: Place your fire extinguisher within arm's reach.
steps.description: The chances are small, but the sparks thrown by drilling metal can sometimes start small fires. A nearby fire extinguisher will help you keep a small fire from getting out of control.

steps.headline: Put on your safety goggles to protect your eyes from thrown debris.
steps.description: You may also want to wear a long-sleeved shirt with a closed collar as well.

steps.headline: Set the drill in place on the divot.
steps.description: Make certain it's set level to the drill angle you want. Newer drills will have integral leveling bubbles to help with this.

steps.headline: Apply steady pressure to drill metal.
steps.description: For hard metals, drill slowly and steadily. Soft metals will require a faster speed because the metal shaving may melt if you go too slowly. Even with soft metals, don't us a speed higher than medium.

steps.headline: Remove your bit immediately when you reach your desired depth.
steps.description: Keep the bit spinning until you've removed it entirely from the metal.

tyn: 2 Drill bits, one sized for your project and one smaller for pilot hole
Hammer and small nail or punch (center)
